awd_titl_txt: Modeling and Solution of Planar Facility Location Problems with  Uncertainty
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will contribute to the national economy, security and prosperity by advancing the state-of-the-art in facility location decision-support tools.  Analytical tools for facility location problems are used for policy and decision making in a wide range of applications, including locating public facilities such as emergency medical centers and fire stations. The increasing dependability on these tools makes it critical to develop more accurate approaches that eliminate potential errors due to aggregation of data and data uncertainty, which in turn could lead to millions of dollars in wasteful expenditure. The goal of this project is to create pathways toward the design of next-generation facility location analytical tools which are error-free and have the capability to account for uncertainties. The collaboration with Roanoke River Cleaning project will inform and validate the developed methodology, as well as demonstrate a meaningful broader impact in the local community. This project will also contribute toward training of undergraduate and graduate students and engaging underrepresented K-12 students in research via established programs at Virginia Tech.

The research objective of this project is to bring a paradigm shift in modeling the classical facility location problems by eliminating critical errors arising from traditional practice of demand aggregation into demand points and binary coverage assumptions. As part of the work, computationally efficient data-driven algorithms will be developed to solve the planar Maximum/Set Covering Location Problems. The developed modeling frameworks allows spatial (non-aggregated) representations of demand and service zones, partial coverage in its true sense, and an adjustable level of risk-aversion to address uncertainty. Exact and approximation algorithms will build on the theoretical properties of the models and result in efficient solution methods.  Extensions to explicitly address uncertainty will also be considered. The PI will evaluate the effectiveness of the models and algorithms by executing a pilot project with the Roanoke River Cleaning Project.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project has contributed to the national economy, security and prosperity by advancing the state-of-the-art in facility location decision-support tools. Analytical tools for facility location problems are used for policy and decision making in a wide range of applications, including locating public facilities such as emergency medical centers and fire stations. The increasing dependability on these tools makes it critical to develop more accurate approaches that incorporate accurate representation of spatial data by eliminating aggregation of data and data uncertainty, which in turn could lead to millions of dollars in wasteful expenditure. The goal of this project has been to create pathways toward the design of next-generation facility location analytical tools which utilize spatial representation of demand and service zones of facilities and have the capability to account for uncertainties. This project has also lead to algorithmic advances in the domain of mathematical optimization, thereby impacting a wide range of application domains. Though beyond the scope of this project, it has also helped in building stepping stones that led to new advances in the domain of stochastic game-theory problems with applications in homeland security.

Intellectual Merits and Technical Contributions. This project has led to theoretical and algorithmic advances for solving the planar Maximum/Set Covering Location Problems (M/SCLPs) that allow spatial (non-aggregated) representations of demand and service zones using rectangles, circles, polygons, etc., partial coverage in its true sense, and an adjustable level of risk-aversion to address uncertainty. Exact, approximation, and heuristic algorithms are presented based on the theoretical properties of the MCLPs. The SCLPs are formulated as semi-infinite binary programs with implicity defined constraints to represent spatial demands as a set of infinite number of demand points, and then a new algorithm is introduced for the semi-infinite programs that is computationally efficient in comparison to the state-of-the-art approaches. To address uncertainty in the facility location problems, this project has led to the development of computationally effective and efficient methodologies for solving stochastic and distributionally robust mixed integer (non)linear program, in general. The foregoing algebraic optimization frameworks allow uncertain input data, incomplete information of the probability distribution associated with the uncertain data, and adjustments baed on the risk-appetite of the decision makers.

Broader Impacts. By incorporating the proposed framework in commercial software such as ArcGIS and TransCAD which still rely on the M/SCLP, the project will help in minimizing the taxpayer-funded infrastructure investments and operational costs required to build and maintain facilities. Four PhD and 11 undergraduate (4 funded by REU supplement) students involved in this project have learned to tackle complex real-world and theoretical problems, which will contribute towards enhancing the performance of sectors that are critical for the U.S. economy and security. This research team has published the findings from this project in high-quality journals (14 papers -- 8 published and 6 at different stages of review process), and has been involvement in a variety of outreach activities with the goal of involving more female/minority/underrepresented students in research projects. For an example, the PI organized workshops on ``Operations Research: An Applied Stream of Mathematics" for low-income first-generation college students in collaboration with Aspire Institute (founded at Harvard University), Cambridge, and the workshop was attended by 100+ and 1250+ students in 2022 and 2023, respectively. The PI has integrate this research into coursework at Virginia Tech which includes (under)-graduate level courses on Linear/Nonlinear Optimization, Deterministic Operations Research, and Stochastic Optimization.
